name: Antioch
shortDescription: Ancient city where followers of Jesus were first called 'Christians,' where Peter served as first bishop, and where Paul and Peter had their famous confrontation over Jewish-Gentile relations.
description: Antioch on the Orontes (modern Antakya, Turkey) was the third-largest city of the Roman Empire and one of the most important centers of early Christianity. Founded by Seleucus I Nicator around 300 BCE, the city became the capital of the Seleucid Empire and later a major Roman metropolis. It was here that followers of Jesus were first called 'Christians' (Acts 11:26). Antioch served as the base for Paul's missionary journeys and the location of the famous 'Antioch Incident' where Paul publicly confronted Peter over eating with Gentile converts (Galatians 2:11-14). According to tradition, Peter served as the first bishop of Antioch before proceeding to Rome. The city became one of the five great patriarchates of ancient Christianity, rivaling Alexandria, Jerusalem, Constantinople, and Rome in ecclesiastical importance.
longDescription:
Antioch holds a unique place in Christian history as the birthplace of the very name 'Christian' and the launching point for the Gentile mission. Its story illuminates the critical transition of the faith from a Jewish sect to a universal religion.

The city was founded around 300 BCE by Seleucus I Nicator, one of Alexander the Great's generals, who named it after his father Antiochus. Strategically located where the Orontes River approached the Mediterranean, Antioch grew to become the third-largest city in the Roman Empire, surpassed only by Rome and Alexandria. Its cosmopolitan population included Greeks, Syrians, Jews, and peoples from across the ancient world.

Following the martyrdom of Stephen and the persecution in Jerusalem (Acts 8), scattered believers carried the Gospel to Antioch. Here, for the first time, they began preaching to Greeks as well as Jews (Acts 11:20). The Jerusalem church sent Barnabas to investigate, and he brought Paul from Tarsus to help teach the growing community. 'And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch' (Acts 11:26).

Antioch became the headquarters for Gentile Christianity and the base for Paul's three missionary journeys. The church there sent out Paul and Barnabas on the first missionary journey (Acts 13:1-3) and received their reports when they returned. The crucial Jerusalem Council (Acts 15) was convened largely to address questions raised by the Antioch church regarding whether Gentile converts needed to follow Jewish law.

Perhaps most significantly for Peter's legacy, Antioch was the site of the 'Antioch Incident' recorded in Galatians 2:11-14. Paul writes: 'But when Peter was come to Antioch, I withstood him to the face, because he was to be blamed. For before that certain came from James, he did eat with the Gentiles: but when they were come, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing them which were of the circumcision.' This confrontation over table fellowship with Gentiles represents a pivotal moment in the Church's development toward full Gentile inclusion.

According to tradition, Peter served as the first bishop of Antioch for seven years before proceeding to Rome. The Antiochene church thus traces its apostolic succession through Peter, making it one of the most ancient episcopal sees. The city became the center of a distinctive theological tradition, emphasizing the literal-historical interpretation of Scripture (contrasted with Alexandria's allegorical approach) and producing great teachers like Ignatius of Antioch, John Chrysostom, and Theodore of Mopsuestia.

The Patriarchate of Antioch was one of the five ancient patriarchates of Christendom. Today, multiple churches claim succession from this ancient see: the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Antioch (based in Damascus), the Syriac Orthodox Church, the Melkite Greek Catholic Church, and others. The city's Christian heritage, though much diminished, continues through these communities.

The ancient city suffered severe damage from earthquakes, including a devastating quake in 526 CE that killed over 250,000 people. Modern Antakya in Turkey preserves archaeological remains and the Cave Church of St. Peter, traditionally associated with Peter's ministry.

mythologyContexts.usage: Antioch was the birthplace of Gentile Christianity, the naming place of 'Christians,' and the base for Paul's missions. Peter served as its first bishop according to tradition.
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Antioch represents the universalization of the Gospel, the resolution of Jewish-Gentile tensions, and the establishment of Christianity as a distinct faith rather than a Jewish sect.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: One of the five ancient patriarchates; center of the Antiochene theological school; location of key events in Acts and Galatians.

historicalDate.display: Active from founding through medieval period

significance: Antioch is where the name 'Christian' originated, where Peter served as first bishop, where Paul launched his missionary journeys, and where the crucial question of Gentile inclusion was worked out in practice. The Antioch Incident between Peter and Paul represents one of the most significant moments of creative tension in early Christianity.
